Graphical abstract Ni loaded mixed metal oxides (MMO) catalysts were systematically synthesized with different Ni/Al ratios through layered double hydroxides (LDH) decomposition, fully characterized using various techniques, and tested in catalytic methane decomposition reaction to study the properties of active nickel species on supports. H2 chemisorption indicated the Ni metallic surface areas on Ni0.5Al-MMO and Ni1Al-MMO were 17.1 and 21.1 m2/g, respectively, which were much higher than those on Ni0.5/Al2O3 and Ni1/Al2O3 impregnated catalysts (at 8.8 and 8.5 m2/g, respectively). However, the MMO catalysts gave the lower carbon nanotubes (CNTs) yield compared with the impregnated catalysts. Form the XPS, XRD and H2-TPR characterizations, it were found that there existed a strong metal and support interaction, leading to less NiO being reduced as the active sites. When Ni/Al ratios increased to 2 and 3, the CNT yields for the NixAl-MMO catalysts were much higher than those of impregnated Ni catalysts, up to 2.02 gc/gcat. and 4.55 gc/gcat., vs 1.36 gc/gcat. and 1.29 gc/gcat., respectively. From H2 chemisorption, we found that NixAl-MMO (x = 2 or 3) catalysts had much higher metallic surface areas (22.3 m2/g and 24.6 m2/g), while they were only 4.9 m2/g and 4.3 m2/g on the impregnated catalysts at the same Ni loadings. It suggests MMO catalysts have more reduced Ni active sites available for methane decomposition reaction, attributing to the proper metal-support interactions. SEM and TEM results display the uniform Ni particle sizes existing on MMO catalysts, giving a nice correlation to the inner diameter of CNTs produced. Keywords Ni metallic surface area NiAl mixed metal oxide catalysts Ni/Al2O3 Metal-support interaction Catalytic methane decomposition 1 Introduction Methane catalytic conversion to nano carbon materials and CO-free H2 is an important reaction and has been attracting considerable attention in recent years [1–9]. That is not only because the nano carbon materials have fascinating and unique physicochemical properties but also have promising applications in gas storage [10–13], catalyst support [14–16] and electrode materials [17–21]. Meanwhile, catalytic methane decomposition (CMD) reaction is a substitution route to steam reforming for the production of CO-free hydrogen which is a highly clean energy carrier applied as fuel in fuel cells [22,23]. To data, catalytic chemical vapor deposition (CCVD) method appears to be the most promising one for preparation of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) with large-scale among various chemical/physical synthesis techniques [24–26]. Methane decomposition is an endothermic reaction which needs high reaction temperature (usually at above 600 °C) to activate methane molecules with the help of catalysts [27]. Currently, studies on the catalysis mainly focus on nickel-, cobalt- and iron- based catalysts [28], and nickel-based catalyst is most commonly used due to its relatively high performance [29]. Awadallah et al. studied [30] the effects of Ti content on 60% Ni/Al2O3 catalyst on the performance of methane decomposition. The results showed that the Ni/TiO2 (25%)-Al2O3 sample exhibited the best activity because the incorporation of TiO2 could reduce the formation of NiAl2O4 spinel structure and increase the reduction of the catalysts. Awadallah et al. [31] also studied the effects of other oxides (Al, Mg, Ce or La oxides) on 50 wt% Ni/SiO2 catalysts prepared by wet impregnation method. They found that both Ni/SiO2-Al2O3 and Ni/SiO2-La2O3 catalysts were most active because of the presence of free mobile surface NiO resulting from the weak interaction with supports. Bayat et al. [32,33] explored the effects of metal dopants (Fe, Cu and Pd) on 50%Ni/Al2O3 catalysts on the performance of methane decomposition. The results indicated both metal Cu and Pd could increase the reducibility/dispersion of nickel on catalyst surface, while Fe decreased the reducibility of nickel catalyst due to the strong interaction between Ni and Fe. Naresh et al. [8] have also explored methane decomposition over Cu promoted nickel-based catalysts supported on Hβ zeolite by impregnation method. The enhanced activity was because of the formation of Ni–Cu alloys and the further improvement on Ni dispersion. These reported studies suggest that the catalyst should have suitable metal-support interaction and enough available activated metal active sites to ensure a high catalytic performance under the experimental conditions. However, the catalysts at high metal loading prepared by impregnation method usually have big particle sizes and low metal dispersion, which limits the catalytic performance in some degrees [34]. Layered double hydroxides (LDHs), known as anionic clay with brucite-like structure, are a class of ionic lamellar compounds composed of positively charged layers and negative anions in the interlayer [35–37], and used for a variety of applications, such as catalysis, ion-exchange and adsorption, electrochemistry [38–40]. With thermal treatment, the layer-structure material can be transferred into mixed metal oxides (MMO), giving a promising way to obtain the well dispersed metal oxide catalysts. Li et al. [41] studied the in situ growth of NiAl and NiMgAl layered double hydroxide (LDH) microcrystallites on microspherical γ-alumina support for acetylene decomposition. The results showed that supported LDH sample calcined at 700 °C possessed higher metal dispersion and carbon yield than that of impregnated sample. Venugopal et al. [42] reported the effects of doped La on NiAl-MMO samples on the catalytic performances of methane decomposition. They found that the addition of La could improve the Ni metal surface area and change the reduction behaviour of NiO particles. Li et al. [43] studied the effects of the amount of Cu on NiAl-MMO catalyst on the performance of methane decomposition and the structure of produced nano carbon materials. Morphologically pure bamboo-shaped carbon filaments were produced under appropriate Cu amount. Pettiti et al. [44] developed a NiMgAl-MMO catalysts derived from hydrotalcite-type (HT) precursors intercalated by silicates, where the silicate altered the formation of the spinel-type phase, decreased the ratio between MgO and MgAl2O4 phases and increased the reduction of nickel oxide. Even though there are several reports on the dopant effects on NiAl-MMO catalysts, to the best of our knowledge, there is a lack of systemically studies on NiAl-MMO catalysts with different Ni loadings. From another point of view, Ni-based catalyst is one of the key catalysts applied not only to methane decomposition, but also to CO methanation [45–47], CH4 dry reforming [48,49], and various hydrogenation reactions [39,50–52], etc. To deepen the understanding of Ni active phase evolution in MMO catalysts, in this contribution, a series of catalysts with different Ni/Al ratios were prepared through LDH decomposition, and tested in catalytic methane decomposition as a model reaction to study the properties of active nickel on supports. With detailed characterizations using Raman, XRD, TEM, N2 adsorption/desorption analysis, H2 chemisorption and SEM, etc, it was found that there was a critical ratio, Ni/Al = 2, to fully utilize the advantages of LDH decomposition method. Below this ratio, although the LDH decomposition catalysts had a higher metallic surface area and smaller particle size, the catalytic performance was worse than those of impregnated samples due to the strong metal-support interactions, leading to a less availability of Ni. However, with the increase of Ni loadings equal or higher than this ratio, the catalytic performance showed an opposite phenomenon. The CNT yield of NiAl-MMO catalyst (Ni/Al = 3) can be 3.5 times higher than the impregnated catalysts at the same Ni loading, attributing to the proper metal-support interaction and much more availabilities of Ni. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The catalysts with different metal molar ratios were prepared by co-precipitation and conventional impregnation methods, respectively. For the samples prepared by co-precipitation methods, an aqueous solution containing nitrate of the metal cations (Ni and Al) with the desired amount was dropped into an aqueous solution of Na2CO3 and NaOH mixture at room temperature. The pH of the reaction mixture was controlled at pH = 10.5 under vigorous stirring. The resulting suspension was aged for 6 h at 60 °C. The final precipitate was filtered, washed thoroughly with DI water for at least three times until pH = 7 and dried in vacuum oven at 60 °C for 24 h, named as NixAl-LDH materials (x is the molar ratio of Ni/Al). The mixed metal oxides with various metal ratios were obtained by calcination of the above precursors at 550 °C for 3 h in air atmosphere at a heating rate of 5 °C/min, which were named as NixAl-MMO (x is the molar ratio of Ni/Al). Typically, for the samples prepared by impregnation method, an appropriate amount of nickel nitrate and activated alumina (Chengdu Kelong Chemical Co., Ltd., China) were mixed together and then 20 ml water was dropped into the above mixture. The samples were evaporated at 60 °C with stirring after impregnation at room temperature for 2 h, followed by drying at 110 °C overnight. Then the impregnation samples were calcinated at 550 °C for 3 h at a heating rate of 5 °C/min, named as Nix/Al2O3 (x is the molar ratio of Ni/Al). 2.2 Characterization of catalysts Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray powder diffractometer with a Cu-Kα source (Kα = 0.154 nm). Elemental analysis was performed using an Agilent VISTA-MPX inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) experiment was carried out using a XSAM800 XPS equipped with an Al Kα (hv = 1486.6 eV) after the reduction of the catalysts at 550 °C for 2 h in the flow of H2. The obtained XPS patterns were calibrated with C1s peak at 284.6 eV. H2-chemisorption experiments were performed on Micromerities 2020 analyzer. Prior to H2 adsorption measurements, around 100 mg sample was in-situ reduced in a flow of H2 at 550 °C for 2 h at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. After the reduction process, the temperature was decreased to 350 °C in a flow of He and hold at this temperature for 60 min in order to remove the residue H2 in system, then hydrogen adsorption measures were carried out at 35 °C. Low-temperature N2 adsorption/desorption measurements were carried out using a Mircromeritics ASAP 2420 instrument. Prior to the measurements, the samples were pre-degassed in vacuum at 200 °C for 24 h. Then the specific surface areas, total pore volumes and average pore diameters of samples were determined from the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms operating at −196 °C. The special surface areas were calculated by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. The total pore volumes were determined from the amount of adsorbed nitrogen at a relative pressure of 0.99. The average pore diameters were determined by the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method applied to desorption isotherms. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was adopted to measure the morphologies of obtained carbon samples on JEOL JSM-6700F field emission instrument at an accelerating voltage of 5 kV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) observations were acquired on a Tecnai TF 20 S-twin electron microscope equipped with quantitative energy dispersive X-ray (EDX). Temperature program reduction of H2 (H2-TPR) measurements were conducted on a fix-bed reactor. 50 mg of fresh sample was loaded into a quartz tube reactor. Before H2-TPR measurement, the sample was treated in Ar flow at 200 °C for 2 h and then cooled down to 100 °C. The sample was reduced in a 5% H2/Ar flow at a heating rate of 10 °C/min and the H2 consumed signal was detected by mass spectrometer with the signal of m/e = 2. In order to calculate the amount of H2 consumed over the different samples, the corresponded experiments were also carried out. Typically, 50 mg fresh sample were loaded into the quartz reactor. Before the experiment, the fresh sample was heated in Ar flow at 200 °C for 2 h and then cooled down to 100 °C. The sample was then reduced in 5% H2/Ar flow with a heating rate of 10 °C/min from 100 °C to 800 °C and hold at 550 °C for 2 h during this process. The amount of reduced nickel was calculated by the total areas before 550 °C. 2.3 Synthesis of carbon nanostructures Synthesis of nano carbon materials was carried out in a fixed bed reactor. Typically, 50 mg fresh Ni based catalysts were placed in the center of quartz tube and heated in Ar flow at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. When reaching 550 °C, the gas was switched to H2 (30 ml/min) and an in-situ reduction was conducted at that temperature for 2 h. Then the reactor was heated to 700 °C in Ar flow at a heating rate of 10 °C/min and the gas was switched to CH4 (50 ml/min) once the temperature reaching to 700 °C. After reacting in CH4 flow at 700 °C for 3 h, the gas was switched to Ar flow and cooled down to room temperature. The carbon yield was calculated as follows: Carbon yield (gc/gcat) = (the total mass after reaction − initial mass of catalyst)/(initial mass of catalyst). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Materials characterization and assignments Fig. 1 (a) showed the powder XRD patterns of the four samples with different Ni/Al ratios. All the tested XRD patterns presented the characteristic reflections of hydrotalcite-like materials [51,53]. However, for the Ni0.5Al-LDH sample, the characteristic peaks of Al(OH)3 co-exist due to the low metal ratio of Ni/Al. Excess Al leaded to Al(OH)3 phase in the materials. Fig. 1(b) showed the composite of these samples measured by Raman spectroscopy. All Raman spectra exhibited the same features except for Ni0.5Al-LDH sample. The wavenumbers located at about 554 and 493 cm–1 can be observed in all samples, which were the characteristic bond of brucite sheets, νNi,Al-OH and δNi,Al-OH [54,55]. For Ni0.5Al-LDH sample, there was an additional lattice vibrational band located at about 530 cm−1, which belonged to the characteristic band of δAl-OH [56]. In addition, the vibration band at about 1060 cm–1 has been detected over the four samples, corresponding to the characteristic bond of δNO3 − [57]. From the XRD and Raman characterizations, it can be confirmed that all the samples own the characteristic reflections of hydrotalcite-like materials, while the Ni0.5Al-LDH sample has the additional characteristic reflection of Al(OH)3 materials due to the low Ni/Al ratio. Fig. 2 showed the curves of weight loss and differential thermal analysis (DTA) over the LDH precursors as a function of temperature, and the curves displayed two well-differentiated weight loss steps from the precursors. At the first stage, from room temperature to 200 °C, the weight loss was mainly due to the remove of interlayer water molecules in LDH. There did not have significant differences among the hydrotalcites studied. The second weight loss, occurring between 200 and 400 °C, was associated to the dehydroxylation of host-layers and decarbonylation of the interlayer, leading to the formation of metal oxides. Above 550 °C, the weight loss was negligible. The two differentiated weight loss peaks for Ni0.5Al-LDH were due to the co-existence of hydrotalcites and Al(OH)3 phases, coming from the over-dosed Al sources inside the materials, as seen from XRD analysis in Fig. 1(a). The mixed oxides materials obtained after calcination were investigated by XRD, as displayed in Fig. 3 . Fig. 3(a) gives the XRD patterns of NiAl-MMO materials. The 2θ at 37.25° (111), 43.28° (200), 63.88° (220), 75.42° (311), and 79.41° (222) were found for all the samples, corresponding to the characteristic peaks of cubic crystalline NiO [58,59]. In addition, there was a special peak for spinal structured NiAl2O4 [JSPDS no. 01-078-1601, Fd-3m, Cubic] observed in Ni0.5Al-MMO sample, suggesting that the Ni components have a strong interface with the support of Al2O3 [60–62]. The XRD powder patterns of the impregnated Ni/Al2O3 catalysts were shown in Fig. 3(b). With the same Ni loadings, the impregnation samples gave much sharper XRD peaks, indicating a larger NiO particle sizes due to the relative weak metal-support interaction. The broad XRD diffraction peaks (Fig. 3(a)) in NiAl-MMO materials suggests much smaller NiO particle sizes compared with those in impregnated samples, suggesting a stronger metal-support interaction over the MMO samples than that of impregnated samples. Table 1 displayed the textual properties of the NixAl-MMO and Nix/Al2O3 materials. It clearly indicated another important advantage of the mixed metal oxides materials prepared through LDH composition. That was giving much higher surface area, total pore volume and smaller pore sizes, compared with the supported metal oxides prepared using impregnation. The surface areas and pore volume for all mixed oxides decreased with the Ni/Al ratio increased. The special surface areas over MMO materials decreased from 263.4 to 174.1 m2/g. However, the special surface areas over the impregnation samples (Nix/Al2O3) were decreased significantly from 116.7 to 73.1 m2/g. This should contribute to the better metal distribution for the samples obtained from LDH materials as the forehead discussion. Meanwhile, it could also be seen from Table 1 that the average pore size increased while the pore volume decreased, along with the increase of metal ratios, suggesting that the high amount of nickel would be likely to block micro-pores of the catalysts [63]. H2-TPR measurements were carried out to study the interaction between nickel species and Al2O3 support over the catalysts with different Ni/Al ratios, as shown in Fig. 4 . For the lower nickel loading MMO materials (Fig. 4(a)), Ni0.5Al-MMO and Ni1Al-MMO, there was mainly one broad reduction peak between 400 °C to 800 °C, indicating the strong interaction between NiO and Al2O3 support. However, there were two reduction peaks in Ni2Al-MMO and Ni3Al-MMO materials, around 570 °C and 700 °C. The temperature of reduction peak was slightly shifted to a lower value with an increasing of NiO amounts, suggesting that the interaction was getting weaker due to the excessively higher amount of nickel. In Fig. 4(b), there were two reduction peaks over the impregnation samples between 100 °C and 800 °C. The low-temperature peak at approximately 430 °C was assigned to the reduction of NiO particles on Al2O3 surface, while the high-temperature peak was attributed to the reduction of highly dispersed NiO species on Al2O3 support [63]. The reduction temperatures of NiO in MMO materials (around 600 °C) were much higher than NiO supported on Al2O3, suggesting a stronger interaction between Ni and alumina support in MMO materials than that of impregnation samples. To compare the interaction between Ni and alumina support in Ni0.5Al-MMO and Ni0.5Al2O3 samples, XPS experiments were carried out as displayed in Fig. 5 . In Fig. 5(a) and (c), the binding energy of Al was 74.51 eV in Ni0.5Al-MMO catalyst, which was higher than that of Ni0.5/Al2O3 catalyst, located at 73.80 eV. It indicates that there were more electrons transferred from Al support to Ni metal in Ni0.5Al-MMO sample, resulting in a relative stronger interaction between Al and Ni. In addition, from Fig. 5(b) and (d), the intensity of Ni0 peak in Ni0.5Al-MMO was much weaker than that of Ni0.5/Al2O3, suggesting that there were less Ni0 species available in Ni0.5Al-MMO due to the stronger interaction between Ni metal and support. The result is consistent with those from H2-TPR analysis in Fig. 4, where the reduction temperatures of NiO species were much higher in Ni0.5Al-MMO sample. H2 chemisorption experiments were carried out to get the nickel dispersion on alumina supports. As presented in Table 2 , Ni dispersion on MMO materials was almost 4–5 times higher than the impregnated materials at the same Ni loadings, leading to the smaller particle sizes and larger metallic surface areas. That should be owed to the special nature of the LDH materials. The ordered and layered prearrangement of metal cations is at the atomic level. After calcination, more activated metal Ni species can be accessed or available, which would give great benefit in catalysis reactions. The XRD patterns of the reduced samples were also investigated, as shown in Fig. 6 (a, b). The diffraction peaks at 2θ = 44.3°, 51.7°, and 76.1° were assigned to the planes of cubic-phased Ni species (JCPDS card No. 65-0380) presented in all of the materials [64–66]. What’s more, diffraction peak of cubic-phased Al2O3 species (JCPDS card No. 29-0063) at 2θ = 66.8° was detected on the Ni0.5Al-MMO and Ni0.5/Al2O3 due to the low Ni loading. The peak intensity for all Nix/Al2O3 impregnated materials was strong and sharp, indicating the well crystallized Ni particles with larger particle size. For NixAl-MMO materials, the XRD peaks were much broad, suggesting that Ni is with much better dispersion and small particle sizes. There were also NiO species over the NixAl-MMO materials detected by XRD. That was because of the strong interaction between Ni and Al2O3 support, resulting difficulties to be fully reduced. In addition, the peak of NiAl2O4 was also be detected over Ni0.5Al-MMO and Ni1Al-MMO samples, as the evidence of the strong interaction inside the MMO materials. To further study the difference of particle sizes over the reduced catalysts, TEM experiments were conducted, as shown in Fig. 7 . It can be seen that the particle sizes over the materials prepared by impregnation were much larger than that of the materials prepared by LDH decomposition, in good agreement with the results in XRD analysis (Fig. 6), and H2 chemisorption (Table 2). As shown in the right part of Fig. 7, the nickel nanoparticles in the impregnation catalysts were seriously agglomerated, especially for the Ni3/Al2O3 catalyst, giving the average particle size at 19.9 nm. However, nano sized nickel was well dispersed in the NixAl-MMO (Fig. 7, left part). The average size of nickel particles was about 3.1 nm on Ni0.5Al-MMO, increasing slowly to 5.6 nm on Ni3Al-MMO, suggesting that the strong interaction between nickel and Al2O3 support. It can prevent nickel’s agglomeration to big particles. The results of HRTEM and element mapping for Ni0.5Al-MMO and Ni0.5/Al2O3 samples were presented in Fig. 8 . As shown in Fig. 8(a) and (b), the lattice spacing of Ni metal in both samples of Ni0.5Al-MMO and Ni0.5/Al2O3 was 0.204 nm, belonging to the (111) plane of the fcc metallic Ni face. From the elemental mapping results in Fig. 8(c) and (d), it can be seen that Ni is well mixed with Al in Ni0.5Al-MMO, while it was aggregated to the big Ni particle size in Ni0.5/Al2O3 sample. The results were nicely consistent with what we got from the TEM analysis in Fig. 7. 3.2 Catalytic performances on methane decomposition reaction The catalytic performances were tested on methane decomposition reaction. The carbon yields were shown in Fig. 9 . On impregnated Nix/Al2O3 catalysts, the best achievement was 1.36 gc/gcat. on Ni2/Al2O3 catalyst. The carbon yield increased as the Ni/Al ratio increased from 0.5:1 to 2:1 due to the increase of reduced metal NiO. However, the carbon yield decreased with further increasing the Ni/Al ratio from 2:1 to 3:1, meaning that the excessively high amount of nickel would not be used in the reaction due to the large particle size and lower metal dispersion over the Ni3/Al2O3 catalyst. For the series of NixAl-MMO catalysts prepared through LDH decomposition, the carbon yields increased with the amount of nickel, from 0.11 gc/gcat. to 4.55 gc/gcat. as the Ni/Al ratio increasing from 0.5:1 to 3:1. Such a carbon yield (4.55 gc/gcat.) was much higher than what we achieved on the impregnated Nix/Al2O3 catalysts and the ones reported in the literature [30]. As reported in the article [67], the activated carbon atom was intended to firstly form NixCy intermediate species and then decomposed at the interface between Ni metal and support to produce carbon materials. Compared with the impregnation samples, the carbon yield over the catalysts of Ni0.5Al-MMO and Ni1Al-MMO was lower than that of Ni0.5/Al2O3 and Ni1/Al2O3 catalysts due to the stronger interaction between Ni metal and support, leading to less Ni available to form NixCy species. However, the carbon yield increased dramatically over the catalysts of Ni2Al-MMO and Ni3Al-MMO, and was significantly higher than that of Ni2/Al2O3 and Ni3/Al2O3 samples, respectively. The results indicated that there should have more activated NixCy species to be used in carbon production over the Ni2Al-MMO and Ni3Al-MMO catalysts, coming from their higher metal dispersion and mild metal support interaction [68]. 3.3 Discussion on relationships between catalytic performance and reduced particle size To unravel the structure-performance relationships, the first thing we have to do is to verify the reduced Ni amount. We measured the amount of H2 consumed during the catalyst pre-activation with H2 within 2 h reduction time at 550 °C to calculate the Nireduced/Nitotal ratios, as shown in Fig. 10 . The general trend is the Nireduced/Nitotal increased with the Ni loadings from 0.5:1 to 3:1, which correlated nicely with the carbon yield produced (Fig. 10b). For Ni1Al-MMO catalyst, the absolute value Nireduced was higher than that of Ni0.5Al-MMO, leading to a higher carbon yield. However, the Nireduced/Nitotal was lower due to the larger Nitotal amount. For Ni3/Al2O3 catalyst, the value of Nireduced/Nitotal was lower than that of Ni2/Al2O3 catalyst due to its bigger particle size. At most of situations, the value of Nireduced/Nitotal for the impregnated samples (Nix/Al2O3) was higher than that for the NixAl-MMO catalysts, suggesting a weaker interaction between NiO species and Al2O3 supports in the impregnated samples. The results were consistent with those from H2-TPR in Fig. 4, XPS in Fig. 5 and XRD in Fig. 6. As compared the values of Nireduced/Nitotal in Ni3/Al2O3 and Ni3Al-MMO catalysts, we noticed the reduced Ni amounts were very close. However, the carbon yields were dramatically different, as 4.55 gc/gcat. vs 1.29 gc/gcat., for Ni3Al-MMO and Ni3/Al2O3, respectively. That means Ni reduced amounts are similar but the efficiency can be quite different. That should be due to the different Ni particle sizes, as shown in Fig. 7 TEM analysis, 5.6 nm vs 19.9 nm, leading to a huge different on metallic surface areas. When the carbon yields was plotted with the reduced Ni particle size, as shown in Fig. 11 , we found a much higher Ni efficiency in NixAl-MMO than Nix/Al2O3, due to the higher metal dispersion and smaller Ni particle size. In another words, the TOF over the samples of NixAl-MMO was much higher than that of Nix/Al2O3 catalysts in the experiment conditions due to their smaller Ni particle size and higher efficiency on utilizing the Ni active sites. 3.4 Discussion on relationships between the diameters of active sites and carbon nanotubes produced Fig. 12 showed the SEM images of the prepared carbon materials over catalysts with different Ni/Al ratios and preparation methods. It can be seen that there were nanotube-like materials produced on every NixAl-MMO catalysts, meaning that nanotube carbon were successfully synthesised. However, much less CNTs were observed over the Ni0.5Al-MMO and Ni1Al-MMO samples due to the strong interaction between nickel species and the support. Pretty more CNT products with uniform outer diameter were observed over the Ni2Al-MMO and Ni3Al-MMO samples. For impregnation samples, the tube carbon materials were prepared with significant lower amounts as shown at the right side of Fig. 9, indicating the less efficiency of Ni catalysts prepared through impregnation. The TEM images of the carbon materials prepared by NixAl-MMO and Nix/Al2O3 catalysts were illustrated in Fig. 13 , it can be seen that nanotube-like carbon materials were obtained on all catalysts. For the NixAl-MMO series catalysts, the inner diameter of the prepared carbon materials was more uniform than that of CNTs obtained on impregnated catalysts attributing to the uniform Ni particle sizes over the catalysts. Moreover, on the impregnated Nix/Al2O3 series samples, the inner diameter distributions were much wider, especially at the higher Ni loadings. The relationships between mean inner diameter of CNT and Ni particle size were drawn in Fig. 14 . It could be seen from Figs. 13 and 14 that the inner diameter of CNTs would become larger with increasing nickel loading due to the bigger particle size over the higher metal loading samples [69,70]. Besides, the inner diameter in MMO samples was smaller than that of impregnation samples, this results further suggested that the particle size in MMO samples was smaller, which were also evidenced by the results of XRD in Fig. 6 and H2 chemisorption in Table 2. Therefore, it can be concluded from the above discussions that the catalysts with a larger particle size would promote the synthesis of bigger inner diameter carbon nanotubes. 4 Conclusions The metal-support interaction and availabilities of metal Ni were adjusted by modifying the ratios of Ni/Al and catalyst structures in the experiment. The carbon yields in catalytic conversions of methane on NixAl-MMO catalysts obtained from LDH decomposition with the relative low metal ratios of Ni/Al at 0.5 and 1 were lower than those on Nix/Al2O3 impregnated catalysts due to the strong metal-support interaction, which made nickel to be hard for a complete reduction. However, with increasing the metal ratios of Ni/Al to 2 and 3, the catalytic performances on NixAl-MMO catalysts were much better than those on Nix/Al2O3 impregnated catalysts because of the smaller and uniform particle size, higher metal dispersion and mild metal-support interaction. It clearly demonstrated the possibilities to prepare the highly dispersed metal catalysts at higher loadings. What’s more, there was a good relationship between the diameter of CNTs produced and the Ni particle size on the support. coredata.dc:description: Ni loaded mixed metal oxides (MMO) catalysts were systematically synthesized with different Ni/Al ratios through layered double hydroxides (LDH) decomposition, fully characterized using various techniques, and tested in catalytic methane decomposition reaction to study the properties of active nickel species on supports. H2 chemisorption indicated the Ni metallic surface areas on Ni0.5Al-MMO and Ni1Al-MMO were 17.1 and 21.1 m2/g, respectively, which were much higher than those on Ni0.5/Al2O3 and Ni1/Al2O3 impregnated catalysts (at 8.8 and 8.5 m2/g, respectively). However, the MMO catalysts gave the lower carbon nanotubes (CNTs) yield compared with the impregnated catalysts. Form the XPS, XRD and H2-TPR characterizations, it were found that there existed a strong metal and support interaction, leading to less NiO being reduced as the active sites. When Ni/Al ratios increased to 2 and 3, the CNT yields for the NixAl-MMO catalysts were much higher than those of impregnated Ni catalysts, up to 2.02 gc/gcat. and 4.55 gc/gcat., vs 1.36 gc/gcat. and 1.29 gc/gcat., respectively. From H2 chemisorption, we found that NixAl-MMO (x = 2 or 3) catalysts had much higher metallic surface areas (22.3 m2/g and 24.6 m2/g), while they were only 4.9 m2/g and 4.3 m2/g on the impregnated catalysts at the same Ni loadings. It suggests MMO catalysts have more reduced Ni active sites available for methane decomposition reaction, attributing to the proper metal-support interactions. SEM and TEM results display the uniform Ni particle sizes existing on MMO catalysts, giving a nice correlation to the inner diameter of CNTs produced.
coredata.dc:title: Insight into the role of metal/oxide interaction and Ni availabilities on NiAl mixed metal oxide catalysts for methane decomposition
